text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
This transmits revised IRM 13.1.9, Taxpayer Advocate Case Procedures, Executive Correspondence Case Procedures.
13.1.9.1 Updated to include the Small Business Administration Office of the National Ombudsman and to incorporate Internal Controls.
Changed related issues to incidental matters for clarity and consistency.
Primarily Taxpayer Advocate Service and all Operating Divisions and Functions.
Bridget Roberts, Deputy National Taxpayer Advocate
Table of Contents
Correspondence Case Procedures 13.1.9 page
Audience: This IRM is for all TAS Case Advocacy employees, including Intake Advocates, Case Advocates, Local Taxpayer Advocates and Analysts.
The following table lists the deﬁnitions for commonly used terms and acronyms as used throughout this IRM:
Term or Acronym Deﬁnition BOD Business Operating Division CA Case Advocate DC Analyst Tax Analyst in the DC LTA office

13.1 Taxpayer Advocate Case Term or Acronym Deﬁnition DC Intake Advocate Intake Advocate in the DC LTA office DC LTA LTA in Washington, DC DEDCA Deputy Executive Director Case Advocacy A system developed using Commercial-Off- The-Shelf (COTS) product Entellitrak for case E-Trak management solutions and business process management solutions ECD Estimated Completion Date EDCA Executive Director Case Advocacy ESCO Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office ITAP Internal Technical Advisor Program LCA Lead Case Advocate LTA Local Taxpayer Advocate NCD Next Contact Date NTA National Taxpayer Advocate NTA-HQ National Taxpayer Advocate headquarters OAR Operations Assistance Request ONO Office of the National Ombudsman SBA Small Business Administration Small Business Regulatory Enforcement SBREFA Fairness Act SFC Senate Finance Committee TAGM Taxpayer Advocate Group Manager Taxpayer Advocate Management Information TAMIS System TAO Taxpayer Assistance Order TAS Taxpayer Advocate Service
) In September

, the Senate Finance Committee (SFC) held oversight hearings on allegations of IRS abuse of taxpayers and their rights. The hearings encouraged taxpayers that felt mistreated by the IRS to come forward.
Case Procedures
page (

) The task force worked with Taxpayer Advocates in the districts and to resolve taxpayers’ complaints and problems. The NTA also charged the force with identifying the underlying causes of these problems and why they were not addressed at the earliest possible opportunity. (
) The SFC Task Force became the SFC Program, permanently located within the Taxpayer Account Operations Office in

) After meeting with the Commissioner and the SFC Chairman to discuss the negative feedback received from constituents, the NTA made procedural changes to establish an independent review process and ensure everything that could be done for taxpayers was considered and no case would be until all actions were completed. (
) The SFC cases are now controlled and monitored in the DC LTA office. (
) The chairmanship of the SFC changes as the majority in the Senate Therefore, procedural changes may need to be made to accommodate the requests of the Ranking Majority Chairman and staff. (

) A taxpayer writes to the SFC regarding a tax matter or the behavior of an employee. The SFC office determines if the correspondence should be to TAS for resolution. The SFC office informs the taxpayer by letter that the correspondence will be forwarded to TAS within
days unless the taxpayer objects to the referral. If the taxpayer does not object, the correspondence is forwarded to TAS for review. (

) The NTA will read the incoming correspondence of the taxpayer, as well as concerns expressed in the cover letter sent by the chairman of the SFC. The NTA will forward the correspondence along with any concerns to the District Columbia (DC) LTA. (

) The DC LTA will ensure that the incoming correspondence is date stamped. The DC Analyst will research the Integrated Data Retrieval System (IDRS), E-Trak system, and the Taxpayer Advocate Management Information System (TAMIS). The DC LTA will determine the appropriate office to work the case. (

) The DC Analyst will prepare and send an acknowledgement letter to the taxpayer advising receipt of the correspondence from the SFC and provide address and phone number of the LTA’s office where the case is assigned. If the taxpayer objects to the LTA handling his or her case after receiving the knowledgement letter, the DC LTA will contact the appropriate Executive Director Case Advocacy (EDCA) or Deputy Executive Director Case (DEDCA) to request the case be worked by a member of the DEDCA staff or by another local TAS office. The DC Analyst will also prepare an ment letter to the chairman of the SFC, for the signature of the NTA. A copy the acknowledgement letter sent to the taxpayer will be enclosed with the to the chairman. Refer to IRM
, Congressional Inquiries, for information on disclosure of taxpayer information to members and committees of Congress. (
) SFC cases are governed by the general case processing rules detailed in
, Processing TAS Cases, in addition to the special guidelines in this section.

quences of non-response will be if the taxpayer does not provide the information. Provide the amount due on the taxpayer’s accounts, including penalty and interest, and provide the date to which the are computed. Update TAMIS with all actions taken and all information received both orally and in writing. (

) If the taxpayer states that he or she needs more time to provide the information, grant a reasonable period of time and update TAMIS. If the taxpayer states that it is not possible to provide the additional information: a. Work the case with the available information if possible; b. Update TAMIS; c. Explain to the taxpayer the consequences involved in resolving the without the information requested; d. Establish and inform the taxpayer of the NCD and revised Estimated Completion Date (ECD) if TAS is able to take further action with the mation available; and e. Record the new NCD and revised ECD on TAMIS. (
) When you receive the information needed to resolve the case, take the action(s) within your authority. (
) Consult or negotiate with Operating Division or Functional Unit contacts to resolve taxpayer issues beyond your authority. See IRM
, TAS tions Assistance Request (OAR) Process for more information on this issue. (
) If you and the Operating Division or Functional Unit contacts cannot agree the resolution, forward your documented case and recommendation to your manager timely per IRM
, OARs - Operating Division or Unit Disagrees - Action Not Taken. If appropriate, issue a TAO. Follow dures outlined in IRM
, TAS Taxpayer Assistance Order (TAO) (
) Update TAMIS with any actions taken within the time frames noted in IRM
, Processing TAS Cases. (

) Before you close a case, review your action plan to ensure all actions have been completed and all incidental matters addressed. If the resolution of taxpayer’s problem will impact a non-related taxpayer, you must also the non-related taxpayer’s issue to completely resolve the TAS case. (
) You are responsible for providing the taxpayer or representative with a complete and correct explanation of what was done to resolve the problem. written closing response is required. Refer to IRM
, Closing Actions. You may use the IRS Style Guide to assist with drafting the closing letter. (
) TAMIS must be documented with all actions taken. The case ﬁle must copies of all correspondence. (
) The following actions need to be completed before you forward your case review: a. Adjustments must be posted (not pending) — Check CC

Work the case with the available information if possible; Update TAMIS; Explain to the taxpayer the consequences involved in resolving the issue without the information requested; Establish and inform the taxpayer of the NCD and revised Estimated Completion Date (ECD) if TAS is able to take further action with the mation available; and Record the new NCD and revised ECD on TAMIS.

Before you close a case, review your action plan to ensure all actions have been completed and all incidental matters addressed. If the resolution of your taxpayer’s problem will impact a non-related taxpayer, you must also address the non-related taxpayer’s issue to completely resolve the TAS case.

) The assigned TAS employee will prepare a draft closing letter for the of the NTA and forward the draft closing letter to the local or servicing TAS Technical Advisor Independent Review Team for review. The closing letter will not be dated or mailed at this time. (
) A Technical Advisor will review SFC cases and their corresponding draft closing letters within

workdays of receipt. The Technical Advisor will an independent review of the case and the closing letter. Neither the LTA or Cases any Technical Advisor who worked on the case will be allowed to review the draft closing letter. (

) SFC Independent Review Team Criteria: • An independent review from the perspective of an advocate. • The letter states that an independent review was conducted. • A technically and procedurally correct conclusion. • All incidental matters addressed. • All IRS errors acknowledged. • Where appropriate, alternative solutions considered and explained. • Complaints regarding employees addressed. • Appropriate tone used in response. • Sufficient documentation. (Would a third party from outside the IRS able to determine what happened? Why?) • Documentation supports the conclusion/resolution reached. • Documentation shows corrective actions completed. • LCA or Technical Advisor’s name, title, address, employee ID phone number, fax number and office hours in the letter. • An appropriate apology is provided in the closing letter. • Taxpayer contact was made by telephone. If a telephone number was available, the reasons why telephone contact was not possible are documented (for non-closing contacts only). • The case ﬁle and TAMIS contains documentation that all promised actions were taken. • When appropriate, TAS has provided or discussed avenues of appeal examination reconsideration, ensuring taxpayers are aware of and derstand how to exercise their right to appeal an IRS decision in an independent forum. (

) Upon completion of the independent case review, the Technical Advisor will take one of the following actions: a. If the Technical Advisor agrees with the closing letter and how the was worked, the letter will be forwarded to the DC LTA along with a of the ﬁle by overnight express for approval and signature by the NTA.
13.1.9.2.3 (08-31-2020) Independent Review Process-SFC Cases

Independent Review Team Criteria: An independent review from the perspective of an advocate. The letter states that an independent review was conducted. A technically and procedurally correct conclusion. All incidental matters addressed. All IRS errors acknowledged. Where appropriate, alternative solutions considered and explained. Complaints regarding employees addressed. Appropriate tone used in response. Sufficient documentation. (Would a third party from outside the IRS be able to determine what happened? Why?) Documentation supports the conclusion/resolution reached. Documentation shows corrective actions completed. LCA or Technical Advisor’s name, title, address, employee ID number, phone number, fax number and office hours in the letter. An appropriate apology is provided in the closing letter. Taxpayer contact was made by telephone. If a telephone number was available, the reasons why telephone contact was not possible are fully documented (for non

closing contacts only). The case ﬁle and TAMIS contains documentation that all promised actions were taken. When appropriate, TAS has provided or discussed avenues of appeal examination reconsideration, ensuring taxpayers are aware of and un
derstand how to exercise their right to appeal an IRS decision in an independent forum.

) The E-Trak coordinator will scan the closing letter into E-Trak and close the E-Trak case. (
) The assigned TAS employee will close the TAS IDRS control bases and release any notice or enforcement holds. (

) E-Trak is a web based Servicewide document tracking application. It is the official tracking system used to process controlled IRS correspondence received in the Executive Secretariat Correspondence Office (ESCO). See
, e-Trak, for additional information. (

) In general, controlled correspondence includes letters, reports and dums that may have an impact on IRS policy and procedures and require coordination. This includes IRS correspondence addressed to the: • President; • Treasury Secretary; • IRS Commissioner; • IRS Deputy Commissioners; and • Director, Legislative Affairs. (
) Business Unit (BU) correspondence includes letters from:

All TAS E-Trak cases should be controlled on TAMIS. The TAMIS case ﬁle number should be annotated in the TAMIS ﬁeld of the E-Trak case.
Note: At no time should a control be reassigned to an office within two workdays of the due date without an interim action being taken.

) The NTA reviews all correspondence addressed to the National Taxpayer Advocate. The NTA may request that a case be opened on TAMIS. Taxpayer on the request, a brieﬁng, case status, or additional information may be Cases requested by the NTA. The NTA will designate whether the DC LTA or a office should retain jurisdiction of the case assignment. The NTA may also request assistance of a speciﬁc attorney advisor. These cases are identiﬁed NTA-HQ cases. (
) After identiﬁcation as an NTA-HQ case by the NTA, the case is transferred the appropriate TAS office to be worked. Case Control (
) All NTA-HQ cases are controlled on TAMIS. On TAMIS, the literal NTAHQ added to the N.O. Use ﬁeld on the Taxpayer Screen
) The DC Analyst will contact the DEDCA and the LTA to advise that a case has been initiated. A copy of the correspondence will be forwarded to both offices. (
) The DC LTA office will assign cases to the designated local TAS office TAMIS. Case (

) Generally, cases are assigned within two workdays from the date the DC office receives the information from the NTA. If a case for the taxpayer currently exists on TAMIS, the local intake advocate will add the NTAHQ nation on the current case. (
) The DC Analyst will provide assistance to the designated LTA, LCA, or Advocate assigned to the case. (
) Cases are worked under general guidelines in IRM
, Processing Cases. Case (

) Unless speciﬁcally assigned to the DC LTA office, the DC LTA staff transfers the NTA-HQ case to a local TAS office based on the location of the the best interest of the taxpayer, prior case activity, open controls and the location of centralized IRS work processes. (
) The designated LTA will review all written responses and ensure adherence quality standards on tax account related inquiries. (
) The CA, TAGM, LTA, or an analyst involved on the case will complete an brieﬁng document. See Exhibit
, National Taxpayer Advocate Case Closing Transmittal. The brieﬁng is reviewed by the LTA in the local office and then sent by secured email to the DC LTA. (

Case Procedures
page (
) Once the NTA approves and signs the requested closing letter, a copy is from the DC Analyst to the local TAS office for the case ﬁle. (
) The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) Office of the National Ombudsman (ONO) was created by Congress in

as part of the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act (SBREFA). The ONO works with federal offices to assist small businesses with unfair and excessive regulatory enforcement, such as repetitive audits or investigations, excessive ﬁnes, penalties, retaliation or other unfair regulatory enforcement action by a federal agency. The ONO receives complaints and comments from small nesses and forwards that information to the appropriate federal agency for a high-level review. Each year the SBA Ombudsman submits a Report to Congress rating the responsiveness of each federal agency. (

) The ONO may receive three types of comments or complaints regarding the IRS: • Case Speciﬁc Comments indicate that the IRS has taken some against the taxpayer (small business) and the taxpayer disagrees with such action. These actions include complaints about collection actions, account problems, audits, misapplied payments, unpaid accounts, penalties and tax assessments. Case-speciﬁc comments are assigned to a Case Advocate as a TAS SBREFA case. • Systemic Comments identify systemic problems that happen on a regular basis. The TAS Office of Systemic Advocacy responds to comments. • General Comments involve questions about tax law, regulations, pliance initiatives, complaints about IRS employee misconduct, letters identifying tax fraud, questions about the burden imposed on by certain laws or procedures, and information requests. The ters Stakeholder Liaison responds to these comments. (

) When the SBA Ombudsman receives a case speciﬁc complaint against the IRS, the SBA Ombudsman will forward the complaint, by fax or by email, to DC LTA. The package from the SBA Ombudsman will include a letter from SBA Ombudsman, the SBA’s Federal Agency Appraisal Form, any dence provided by the small business owner, and a Form
, Tax Information Authorization. The original documents are later mailed to the DC LTA office. (
) Within ﬁve workdays of receipt by the DC LTA office, the DC Analyst reviews the incoming documents to determine if a referral to a local TAS office is ap- propriate. (
) If a referral is appropriate, the DC Analyst routes the documents to the DC Intake Advocate to create a case on TAMIS using special case code “

) Within ﬁve workdays of receipt by the DC LTA office, the DC Analyst will transfer the case on TAMIS and forward the SBA Ombudsman package to local TAS office. The DC Analyst will notify the LTA and the Area SBREFA Analyst that a new SBREFA case has been transferred to the local office. (
) Upon receipt, the designated LTA will assign the case to a Case Advocate. (
) Original SBA correspondence will remain in the DC LTA office. Internal Revenue Manual

Once the NTA approves and signs the requested closing letter, a copy is from the DC Analyst to the local TAS office for the case ﬁle. The U.S. Small Business Administration (SBA) Office of the National Ombudsman (ONO) was created by Congress in

as part of the Small Business Regulatory Enforcement Fairness Act (SBREFA). The ONO works with federal offices to assist small businesses with unfair and excessive regulatory enforcement, such as repetitive audits or investigations, ﬁnes, penalties, retaliation or other unfair regulatory enforcement action by a federal agency. The ONO receives complaints and comments from small nesses and forwards that information to the appropriate federal agency for a high-level review. Each year the SBA Ombudsman submits a Report to Congress rating the responsiveness of each federal agency. The ONO may receive three types of comments or complaints regarding the IRS: • Case Speciﬁc Comments indicate that the IRS has taken some against the taxpayer (small business) and the taxpayer disagrees such action. These actions include complaints about collection account problems, audits, misapplied payments, unpaid accounts, penalties and tax assessments. Case-speciﬁc comments are to a Case Advocate as a TAS SBREFA case. • Systemic Comments identify systemic problems that happen on a regular basis. The TAS Office of Systemic Advocacy responds to comments. • General Comments involve questions about tax law, regulations, pliance initiatives, complaints about IRS employee misconduct, letters identifying tax fraud, questions about the burden imposed on by certain laws or procedures, and information requests. The ters Stakeholder Liaison responds to these comments.
Once the NTA approves and signs the requested closing letter, a copy is from the DC Analyst to the local TAS office for the case ﬁle.

procedures are as follows: Within ﬁve workdays of receipt, the LTA will prepare a letter to the SBA Ombudsman to acknowledge receipt of the SBA correspondence and provide the assigned Case Advocate’s contact information. Within ﬁve workdays of assignment, the Case Advocate will make contact with the taxpayer or POA, following the procedures in IRM

, Initial Contact. The initial contact, whether by telephone or in writing, will include a statement that the taxpayer’s complaint ﬁled with SBA has been referred to TAS for resolution. The initial contact will include a request for a properly completed Form

, if necessary. Consult ITAP, if necessary, to ensure all avenues of advocacy are ered. Any remaining balance should be resolved. Assist the taxpayer with an installment agreement, offer in compromise or currently not collectable determination if appropriate. The Case Advocate will prepare an interim response letter to the SBA Ombudsman every

days from the date of the LTA acknowledgement letter, to update the SBA Ombudsman on the progress of the case. The closing contact with the taxpayer, whether by telephone or in will include a statement that a separate closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman will be signed by the DC LTA. See IRM
for the procedures on the closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman.

When all casework is complete, a draft closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman will be forwarded by secure email to the DC Analyst. The draft closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman may be prepared by the Advocate, a Technical Advisor or an Area Analyst for the DC LTA’s review signature. The letter is prepared from an advocate’s perspective in a plain, straightforward language. The IRS Style Guide may be used to assist with drafting the closing letter. The draft closing letter must: a. contain plain language with no IRS jargon, technical language on IRS procedures, or a complex explanation of technical tax law; b. provide a summary of the taxpayer’s complaint. If the complaint ﬁled SBA is vague, the Case Advocate should clarify the exact issue, such lien release, installment agreement, penalty abatement, etc., during the initial contact with the taxpayer; c. provide a comprehensive, but concise, chronological summary of facts. A good summary will provide exact dates of signiﬁcant actions, the correct number and title of IRS forms, letters and notices;

will be forwarded by secure email to the DC Analyst. The letter is prepared from an advocate’s perspective in a plain, straightforward language. The IRS Style Guide may be used to assist with drafting the closing letter. The draft closing letter must:

a. contain plain language with no IRS jargon, technical language on IRS procedures, or a complex explanation of technical tax law; b. provide a summary of the taxpayer’s complaint. If the complaint ﬁled with SBA is vague, the Case Advocate should clarify the exact issue, such as lien release, installment agreement, penalty abatement, etc., during the initial contact with the taxpayer; c. provide a comprehensive, but concise, chronological summary of relevant facts. A good summary will provide exact dates of signiﬁcant actions, and the correct number and title of IRS forms, letters and notices;

) The DC Analyst will review the draft closing letter and consult with the Case Advocate or a Technical Advisor, as appropriate, to resolve any questions request copies of additional documentation secured while working the case. The DC Analyst will update the case history on TAMIS with appropriate comments as the case is forwarded and reviewed by the DC LTA. (

) When the closing letter is signed by the DC LTA, the DC Analyst will send letter to the SBA Ombudsman by fax or secure email. The original will be mailed directly from the DC LTA office. The DC Analyst will forward a copy the closing letter to the Case Advocate, the LTA and the Area Analyst by secure email. (
) A SBREFA case will be closed in the same manner as a TAS Criteria
as provided in IRM
, TAS Case Closing and Reopen Case subject to the additional items identiﬁed earlier. The case will remain open the closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman is signed by the DC LTA. (
) A SBREFA case may be closed as a withdrawal, as provided in IRM
, Withdrawal of TAS Cases, and will be addressed in the draft closing letter to the SBA Ombudsman. (
) If the taxpayer withdraws the complaint ﬁled with the SBA Ombudsman, the DC Analyst will contact the SBA ONO for a determination if a closing letter necessary. (
) A SBREFA case may be reopened, as provided in IRM
, Cases, either through correspondence from the SBA Ombudsman, direct contact from the taxpayer, or as directed by the NTA.
The case will be placed in Monitor status on TAMIS and remain open until the closing letter, signed by the DC LTA, is received from the DC Analyst.
Note: The CA will continue to send the interim letter to the SBA Ombudsman every 30 days until the DC LTA issues the closing letter..
